Articles.Content: Floor 4394: The floor is covered in boiling water and there are Tea Trees on raised platforms that are constantly dropping leaves into the water. You see some piping that that transports the boiled tea to the Dragon below.

Floor 4395: a dragon drinking tea, earl grey, hot. It has a sign that says: This is a new page, a new floor. Scones are on the next floor with a Tyrannosaur and Allosaur giving them out

———

182312272023

new page
Floor 4396: A dyno counter. One ceratops. Two ceratops. Three ceratops.
Floor 4397: A sock counter. One pair of socks, two pairs of socks, three pairs of socks....
Floor 4398: Someone very confused and frustrated, sitting at a computer. You walk closer and see that he is trying to navigate the Jool system via gravity assists.
Floor 4399: A repaired sock counter. One sock, two socks, three socks....
Floor 4400: A small sign saying: "In 44 floors, we will reach Floor 4444. Nice."

Floor 4402: A single aircraft hangar in the middle of an empty void. It is said to contain the greatest fighter jet in the world, but everyone is arguing what it is. You look over and see a forum user standing in a corner trying to explain why it's the F/A-18E/F Super Hornet.
Floor 4403: The F/A-1/8E/F Super/Hornet
Floor: 4404: Someone from Floor 4402 escaping a crowd of angry pursuers. It seems that they said that the F-35 Lightning II was the best fighter jet.

Floor 4405: The Joros Subsystems J35 VTOL, a kerbal equivalent of the F35, designed by yours truly. Jeb is climbing into the pilot's seat and is about to pass out with glee. Bob is reluctantly climbing into the navigator's seat and is about to pass out with dread.

Floor 4406: My Kerbalverse's Jeb, flying in my handcrafted, armed, accurate, extremely modded, organic F/A-18E Super Hornet. He challenges the J-35 to a dogfight!

Spoiler

F/A-18E "Echo-1"'s loadout:

  • Vulcan cannon
  • AIM-120 AMRAAM, x4
  • AIM-9 Sidewinder, x6
  • Flares and chaffs
  • Three drop-tanks.

More info on the plane:

  • A single seat cockpit, with modernized "glass cockpit" controls.
  • Twin afterburning jet engines (non-thrust vectoring) capable of taking the jet to supersonic speeds.
  • Highly maneuverable, but not as maneuverable as a, say, F-16 or F-22.
  • Capable of launching and landing off of aircraft carriers.

 

Edited December 29, 2023 by TwoCalories
Added more stuff

Floor 4407: The dogfight between the J35 and the F/A-18E Super Hornet.

While the Hornet has much more weaponry, the J35 has highly advanced maneuverability. It pulls a Pugachev Cobra on the Hornet, giving it a chance to fire one of its two experimental missiles at it. 

Spoiler

Joros Subsystems J35 VTOL "Peregrine" stats:

  • 2 Experimental Firebird Missiles
  • VTOL: Dedicated front lift engines, rear swivels down
  • Advanced maneuverability and near-complete control during a stall
  • Extremely short takeoff run non-VTOL. Could liftoff from the VAB helipads, if necessary.

Floor 4408: The live view of the dogfight continues.

The Hornet pulls a high-G turn, causing the missile to lose its lock. By doing this turn, the Hornet lost enough airspeed to end up behind the Peregrine once again. The pilot takes advantage of this and fires its Vulcan cannon.

Floor 4409: A science museum

182912292023

Floor 4410: The planes from Floors 4405-4408 continue to dogfight. The Peregrine managed to pull an evasive maneuver, only taking some light damage to its right wing. The two planes are now locked in a Flat Scissors maneuver.

Floor 4411: The dogfight continues. The Peregrine pulls off a trick labeled in its instruction manual as: "No, Jeb. Just no." It activates its front lift engines, pitching up rapidly and pulling out of the scissors. Tumbling end over end, it shuts off the front engines and uses its main engine gimbal to cancel the rotation. It's now at point-blank range of the Hornet and fires its other Firebird missile right into the Hornet's engines.

Floor 4412: The Hornet is torn in half in a violent explosion by the Firebird missile, forcing the pilot to eject. However, the Peregrine, being so close to the exploding Hornet, is totally shredded by the debris and shrapnel. Somehow, Jeb and Bob were able to bail out in time and meet up on the ground with the Hornet pilot. Both planes were destroyed.

"So... uh... wanna do a rematch?"

Edited December 30, 2023 by TwoCalories

Floor 4413: The crew of both ships have met up in a cafe and now share their experiences of the dogfight. They have become fast friends. At one of the other tables, Bill absentmindedly draws a revolutionary plane design on his napkin.
Floor 4414: A sign that says "In 30 floors there will be a palindrome"

Floor 4415: The plane that Bill Kerman designed on Floor 4413 is now put into testing. The plane is being called the K-40 Ocelot. The Ocelot is being put up against an F/A-18E Super Hornet for mock-combat (dogfighting until you get a lock on the other aircraft) trials.

The F/A-18E starts off by taking the offensive, throttling down its engines to get behind the Ocelot.

Floor 4416: The Ocelot throttles down as well, putting it at the same speed as the Hornet. From the stands, (yes, others are watching this) a new group of pilots watches and learns. From the wide berth they are given, it can be assumed they are working on a secret project.
Floor 4417: The Hornet pilot pulls out all the safeties and limiters. pulling off a Cobra maneuver, getting behind the Ocelot.

Floor 4418: a sign that reads: May 2024 bring peace, love, justice and positivity.

170901012024
